author: Jordan Heck (jordan.heck@performgroup.com)
title: James Dolan bans Charles Oakley from MSG, alleges ex-player has drinking problem
text:
February 10, 2017 4:31pm EST February 10, 2017 3:44pm EST Basketball, NBA, News, New York Knicks, English The former Knicks player is no longer welcome at the arena he called home for a decade. Charles Oakley (Getty Images) 
Updated at 4:31 p.m. ET 
Updated at 4:31 p.m. ET 
Charles Oakley's arrest Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden has reportedly in a permanent ban from the arena. 
Knicks owner James Dolan appeared on the Michael Kay show Friday evening and confirmed the report from half an hour earlier. While he did confirm the ban, he said, "Hopefully it won’t be forever.” 
MORE: Charles Oakley admits to drinking before arrest 
Dolan admits he's concerned about the backlash from fans, but says safety is more important saying, "It’s clear Charles Oakley came to the Garden with an agenda.” Says he was "terribly abusive" towards people at the Garden and he used "racial overtones" and "sexual overtones" towards the staff there. "I understand that he was a big star, but that doesn't excuse people from that type of behavior." -James Dolan on Oakley ban from MSG — The Michael Kay Show (@TMKSESPN) February 10, 2017 
"From the moment he walked through the first set of doors, he began with this behavior. Abusive behavior," Dolan continued. "We weren't perfect here and I think Charles should've never made it to his seats. That's on us." James Dolan: "Charles has a problem. He's his own worst problem. ... people need to understand that." — Tim Bontemps (@TimBontemps) February 10, 2017 
The news comes just a few hours after it was reported the Knicks fired Frank Benedetto, the senior vice president of security at MSG. 
Also, around the same time, Madison Square Garden released statements from employees who witnessed Oakley's behaivor Wednesday night. One employee claimed Oakley was yelling, “You got all those f—ing security people over them looking at me. I don’t know what the f— they’re looking at, but they’re getting on my f—ing nerves." 
Oakley had admitted Thursday night in an interview to drinking before Wednesday's incident, and an employee confirmed the former player “seemed pretty inebriated." Dolan also seemed concerned with Oakley's drinking and his behavior. 
Dolan said Oakley had a "problem with anger" and added "he may have a problem with alcohol, we don't know." He continued by mentioning the Knicks statement claiming Oakley needs help, and agreed: “I do think Charles needs help...He’s had many physical altercations, he’s been arrested…it all seems to stem from his anger."
